Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Clean Air Exhuast Lines Explosion Isolation Device for Combustible Dust Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to provide a safer working environment for powder bulk handling facilities, while simultaneously helping the facility reduce its energy consumption by allowing it to recycle conditioned air back into the building. The risk associated with combustible dusts are catastrophic, yet the awareness of the risks is still lacking. Commercially, this project would design a product that would be installed at powder bulk handling facilities, that handle combustible dust, that would prevent fire propagation from the combustion of dust from entering the work area of the facility.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are developing an economical device which will act as a flame and pressure arrestor for dust deflagrations, while maintaining enough airflow through the device to allow the process to be balanced. Determining an appropriate stack-up of mesh material that will quench the propagating deflagration, while also withstand the pressures developed during a deflagration, will also help expand the field of knowledge of combustible dust, and developing protection equipment for them. Through the development of this product, additional full scale test will have to be performed which will add to the database of how combustible dust events occur and react.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Phase I proposal was working on developing a new explosion isolation device for clean air exhaust lines. Due to changes in NFPA regulations, facilities handling combustible dust must now provide explosion isolation on clean air exhaust lines that recycle the filtered air back into the facility. This new rule has caused many facilities to have to exhaust their already conditioned (heated or cooled) facility air outside, increasing their utility bill and their carbon footprint. The device this project was working on developing would provide an economical solution to the new NFPA requirements, allowing customers to safely keep exhausting their clean air lines in their facilities.

To solve the issue of explosion isolation this project decided to develop a quench valve, that would act as in in-line isolation device but would still be economical enough that the capital investment of installing them would offset the reclaimed energy savings. The challenges with designing this device was balancing the correct amount of quenching material while preventing the device from causing to great of a pressure drop in the exhaust line, causing the end user from having to re-engineer the entire system.  

We first reviewed with many different air material separator companies to determine what an allowable pressure drop in a system without causing the system to become unbalanced. After reviewing with multiple companies, we then developed a mathematical model that we believed allowed us to accurately predict what the pressure drop of a given stack up of mesh layers would be. Once our model was established, we then needed to verify that our model was accurate. We designed and developed prototype quench valves and took the prototypes to a testing to facility to measure the pressure drop across them in a real-world scenario. Once collecting the data from the test facility, we compared the actual results to our calculated results, finding that our model was within the range of error for our model. This means we could not predict a given mesh stack-ups pressure drop and be able to determine an optimal stack up that would ensure explosion isolation with minimal pressure drop in the system.

Now that this information was determined the project can move forward with the development of the prototypes and began actual full-scale testing to determine the actual feasibility of using such a device.  If full scale testing proves successful then the device would have to be tested by a third-party agency to receive the appropriate approval listings.
